title: 115_hr3260
content: The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" may be cited as the Act. It establishes physical standards for airlines. The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" establishes physical standards for airlines, including minimum seat and bathroom dimensions to be determined by the Secretary of Transportation in consultation with relevant groups. The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" sets standards for airlines, including bathroom dimensions, door size, toilet size, safety, and health requirements in consultation with various groups. The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" establishes standards for airlines, including passenger protections. The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" mandates specific rights for passengers, including refunds for damaged amenities, fines for dishonest cancellation claims, and compensation for delays not caused by force majeure. The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" requires airlines to provide replacement tickets or refunds for passengers whose flights are delayed by 3 or more hours, and to notify passengers at least 3 hours in advance of any economic delays or cancellations. The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" mandates airlines to offer ticket refunds or alternate transportation to passengers in case of flight cancellations. Airlines must disclose fees upfront and ensure they are not excessively high. Additionally, airlines are required to report basic statistics on frequent flier programs and notify passengers in advance of any benefit reductions. The "Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017" requires airlines to provide refunds or alternate transportation for flight cancellations. Airlines must disclose fees upfront, report frequent flier program statistics, and notify passengers in advance of benefit reductions. 10 percent of fines paid by airlines for violations will fund a consumer complaint hotline and passenger claims arbitration system. The Secretary shall ensure that airlines comply with the Uniform Unclaimed Property Act for lost baggage and offer excess value insurance. Airlines must inform customers of their rights, liabilities, and recourse in case of disputes. The Secretary will reinstate the reciprocity rule for flight cancellations and delays, allowing passengers to use their ticket on another airline. Airlines will be fined for tarmac delays and must provide basic necessities to passengers. The Act requires airlines to provide basic necessities like water and lavatories to passengers after a 2-hour tarmac delay. Definitions for "Secretary" and "force majeure" are also provided in the Act. The Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017 amends Title 49 to require air carriers to develop reserve staffing and equipment plans to minimize flight cancellations and delays within their control. The Act also mandates guidelines and reporting requirements for compliance. The Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017 mandates air carriers to report cancellation and on-time performance statistics to the FAA annually. The Secretary will fine carriers for non-compliance due to failure in reserve staffing and equipment plans. The Airline Passenger Protection Act of 2017 requires air carriers to report cancellation and on-time performance data to the FAA. The Secretary can impose fines on carriers for not meeting reserve staffing and equipment requirements.
